content: that's what they want me to paint yeah I'll do that
hey guys welcome back to Blackmagic
craft this video is sponsored by wicked foundations they are in the middle of a
Kickstarter for a range of truly gruesome and horrific miniatures for D&D
5 e well I guess you could use them for anything but they're marketing them for
5e they approached me with an idea I couldn't say no to they wanted me to
paint one of their diurnal beast miniatures and this thing is just super
cool so I'm doing it I am by no means an expert miniature painter so I'm not
gonna just be painting this thing I actually decided to compensate for my
lack of painting abilities by constructing a really cool removable
diorama base which of course you could take these principles and apply it to
any miniature you'd like I think it really does this miniature justice the
Kickstarter that they're running is all about creepy monsters really big creepy
monsters some of them are huge and this is not for downloadable STL files for
you to print yourself these are intended to be physical miniatures injection
molded plastic the real deal and they like I said are designed for 5e and part
of that campaign is actually this little Monster Manual that they've created with
stat blocks and lore for all of the miniatures I will of course put links in
the video description below to the Kickstarter so you can check it out in
detail for yourselves but now let's talk about how I put this thing together the
first thing I did with this model after swooning over its coolness was prime it
I knew I wanted to paint this thing using some citadel contrast paint
because again I'm not an amazing mini painter and I figured contrast paints
would help me with some of the more difficult aspects of this model like the
black hair so I primed it with this Citadel Wraith bone primer that they
recommend for the contrast paints and it did a very nice job it applied my
and it dried very quickly but my god this is the most disgusting
foul-smelling primer I've ever used it's like they bottled burnt hair farts and
toxic waste but did a nice job before getting to paint though I worked on
constructing the removable base I wanted like a big rock for this thing to be
perched on in my head I was picturing something like The Rock in The Lion King
but more creepy and evil I grabbed a piece of thick XPS foam and use my
handheld hot wire cutter to start carving in layers of stone I had to be
careful to leave enough area on the top to surround the actual model base I
attached the foam to some medium weight chipboard to give it a more durable
bottom MDF would definitely be a better material for this but you just can't
beat the speed and ease of use of chipboard now here's where my first
screw-up happened I planned on using sculpt amoled to cover the foam to give
it more strength and a more realistic stone texture I got out with my bag of
sculpt and mold and some cups to mix it in when I grabbed the cups I noticed one
already had some in it I was guessing it was leftover from last time cool I
thought and started mixing I decided to test out mixing in some black paint to
see how it reacted covered my piece and something didn't seem right it wasn't
applying or acting the way it should it was just really creamy but I didn't give
it any more thought not until it was drying did I realize what was actually
going on it wasn't sculpt a mold in the cup that I had found it was quick-set
drywall joint compound this is basically only one part of the sculpt to mold
missing the paper fibers that give sculpt a mold its strength this really
wouldn't work as well as the sculpt a mold like I planned my god I am saying
sculpt a mold a lot I decided that I really needed to go forward with my
original plan so I actually just mixed up some real sculpt the mold and covered
the joint compound and I wasn't sure how these two materials would react because
the joint compound wasn't fully cured but I decided to say screw it and hope
for the best with the sculpt the mold in place
I created a recess of the mini bass to fit into I really
wanted the two pieces to blend together as best as I could get them it was a
little tricky doing this with the wet product as taking it out just pulled the
sculpt amoled and distorted the edge so I took another risk and let it dry in
place with the hopes that I could later remove the model without issue the great
thing about sculpting mold is that once it's mostly dry but not fully dry you
can easily tool it to look like stone the trick is really not waiting until
it's fully cured I coated my base with my usual black paint and Mod Podge
mixture this over the sculpt amoled makes the foam way harder and more
durable than you'd expect while that dried I set to work actually
painting the model the part of the project I was nervous about not only am
I not that great of a mini painter in all honesty I only paint a mini or two a
month at best I got hundreds of mini sitting waiting to be painted I also
wanted to do the paint job in a way that was true to the source art which meant
doing some things that were beyond my comfort and skill level like trying to
paint the horse body a very light gray with shadowy black areas and darker legs
and hand yeah this thing has legs and hands super creepy relying on the
so-called magic of contrast paint I attacked it with the black first
painting the legs with the stuff straight out of the bottle then doing
the body with a diluted mix that I cut with contrast medium this worked pretty
okay the black contrast paint worked very well for the hair however creating
a look of hair that was believably black but still retained highlights and
definition I painted the flower petals using some diluted red contrast paint
and also carried some of that onto the legs in the source art the legs looked
black but it appeared that they may actually be red and just shadowed in the
art so I was hoping to retain some of that sort of look for the skull I used
the red contrast paint right out of the pot and this created a really vibrant
deep read look here's where my painting
skills started to fall short the contrast paint did an okay job on
the body but still looked rather messy so I needed to highlight with a lighter
gray but this is really easier said than done and I always struggle with doing
this on big smooth muscular areas of bodies my combination of lower skill and
impatience usually result in a pretty chalky look when I do this I played
around and got it as good as I could or at least as good as I could in the time
I could handle spending on it listen I'm just not the type of person that can
spend hours and hours painting one part of a model blending it perfectly I just
I just want to get in and get it done the pedals were also looking to read as
compared to the concept art so I attempted to lighten them up and make
them more pink not only would this make it match the art better but it would
also create a nice contrast to the blood-red skull again my blending skills
struggled here but I was able to get them to a point I was a lot more happy
with than the body I also didn't like how the transition of the dark legs to
the light body was looking so I decided to paint in some thin tendril like lines
to create a creepy transition and I actually think this came out looking
pretty cool but before painting out the model base I have to finish up the
diorama one so that they could be painted in tandem I didn't think the
stone was interesting enough on its own I wanted to cover it in remains from
this thing's previous kills I grabbed a bunch of stuff where I could grab skulls
and bones from I even utilized some tiny skeletons from a super-secret project
this is something I have going on in the background slowly that I can't really
talk about yet sorry but the citadel skull box and some of the leftovers from
my Frost grave cultists really got put to good use here this part was actually
really important the thing about the models from this Kickstarter is that
most of them are big like really really big some are more than double the size
of this one and the creators are aware of this and even have a size graph on
the page they are meant to be big monsters and the stat blocks reflect
that the one thing that's kind of strange is
that this model has skeletal remains underneath it and they're the same size
and scale as the beast itself definitely a lot bigger than a 28 millimeter
humanoid so I decided that the reason for that is that these creatures are
territorial and maybe cannibalistic and these are actually the remains of
another diurnal beast that's what I'm telling myself so I figured putting on
some more appropriate size 28 millimeter skulls and bones onto the base would
kind of make the whole thing make more sense and be more cohesive with other
minis using superglue and sand I decorated the steps of this base with
the creatures previous kills this right here is my favorite part of miniature
painting honestly I don't really care that much about painting minis nor do I
enjoy it that much it's just something I need to get done half the time but what
I really love is decorating the bases that's my jam i primed out the big base
to match the small one and decided to get a stone effect with black and brown
washes over the light primer rather than building up layers of lighter and
lighter dry brushing this effect can look a lot more natural when it works
and is honestly super easy to do blending the black and brown washes
gives a lot of variation to the tone one important detail is that I did some of
this with the mini in place on the base so that any color streaks carried
between the two of them in order to make them look like they were actually from
the same piece of rock normally I would just seal a mini with satin or matte
varnish but in this case I wanted there to be a few different gloss levels to
the different parts I sprayed everything out with a matte varnish but then use
satin for the flower petals and the body to give them a tiny bit of Sheen then I
used a fully gloss varnish on the skull to really make it stand out and look
more wet and slimy I also created a bit of blood effect by mixing Vallejo water
texture with some of the red contrast paint you can do this with any acrylic
paint or ink but I use the contrast paint as
would match what I had already painted on the model one fun thing is that you
can paint streaks of this stuff on plastic let it dry and then peel it off
and glue it to the model to create realistic looking drips of blood so what
can I say I love this model I love the whole line of Manos these
guys have created their creepy aesthetic is right up my alley this is the type of
stuff I naturally make for my own homebrew world I'm always gonna prefer
some creepy skull flower scent or thing over an orc or goblin if you're the same
way well I really encourage you to check out the Kickstarter they got going
because it is full of creepy miniatures again I will put the link to the
Kickstarter in the description below I really hope this one funds as I love
seeing companies doing unique lines of minis and creating actual physical
miniatures for the market not just downloadable files for those who have 3d
printers I really hope you found this video enjoyable and informative even if
you're not interested in the Kickstarter I'm hoping you get some inspiration and
learn something about making custom diorama bases for your models if you
want to grab any tools or supplies for your own ha being head over to
Blackmagic craft CA there I have my essential equipment page where I list
all of the stuff or most of the stuff that I use regularly I explain what it
is and why I use it and I give you links to the product so you can get the right
thing for yourself and if you really like my videos and get a lot of value
out of them one way that you can help ensure that I'm able to keep making them
is by supporting black magic crafts on patreon it's because of the support
there that I'm able to dedicate all my time to such a kind of ridiculous
adventure of making this stuff on YouTube I would love to have your
support and doing so gives you some access to some kind of fun rewards like
my private Facebook group and discord server where you can ask me questions
get help from me and other really cool like-minded crafters that's it for this
week guys see you again next week Cheers
